Description: Lower body and foot sherd of Corinthian pottery open vessel, probably a krater; interior glazed (mostly worn); exterior glazed with trace of added red bands around foot; reserved underside; inscription on underside.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis), Stratum APo30
Curator's comments: For parallels, see KOCYBALA, A. ‘The Corinthian Pottery’, in D. White (ed.) The Extramural Sanctuary of Demeter and Persephone at Cyrene, Libya Final Reports VII. Philadelphia, 1999, no. 289. According to Weinberg (in WEINBERG, S.S. 'The Geometric and Orientalizing Pottery', in Corinth VII: I, 1943, 63, no. 233), EC black-glazed column-kraters were decorated with red and white bands. This feature does not continue into the later periods. See also WEINBERG, S.S. Hesperia, Vol. 17,No. 3, 1948, pl. LXXIX, D13. The context number APo30 is written in pencil on the underside of the foot.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.214) (phase 3)
